question: Question_A_04
sols:
Recall the conditions for a unique solution, no solution and an infinite
number of solutions. For a unique solution, the row reduced matrix must
be the identity matrix so that each unknown has precisely one determined
value (hence unique). For no solutions to occur we need either a
contradiction (i.e. trying to determine that an unknown takes on two
values) or we need an impossible situation (i.e. trying to determine
that 0x=7). For an infinite number of solutions we need a free variable
in the form 0z=0.

We have 4 equations and 3 unknowns so our matrix is $4\times{3}$. We are
trying to determine three variables with 4 conditions. Recall that to
determine n unknowns we need exactly n equations (i.e. we only need 3
conditions here). Therefore, the only way we will get a unique solution
is if one of the equations is redundant information (so that in
actuality we only have 3 conditions). This would appear in the matrix as
a row of zeros (since one row will be a multiple of another). For
example, consider a system row reduced as follows

\begin{align*}\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1  &  0  &  0 & 7\\
0  & 1  &  0  &  2\\
0  &  0  &  1  & 4\\
0  &  0  &  0  &  0
\end{array}\right].\end{align*}

If we call our unknowns, x,y, and z then we see that x=7, y=2, z=4 and
then the last row tells us 0x+0y+0z=0 which holds true and so we have a
\textbf{unique} solution.

If the 4th condition was not simply redundant information but rather a
independent condition then we could row reduce to get something of the
form

\begin{align*}\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1  &  0  &  0 & 7\\
0  & 1  &  0  &  2\\
0  &  0  &  1  & 4\\
0  &  0  &  0  &  12
\end{array}\right].\end{align*}

Here we still are determining that x=7, y=2, and z=4 but we also require
that 0x+0y+0z=12 which doesn't hold true for these values (in fact it
will never hold true) and therefore all 4 conditions can't be satisfied
so this results in \textbf{no solution}.

We have considered when there is no redundancy in the constraints and
when one condition is redundant. What if multiple conditions are
redundant? Let's say we have a model with the following constraints

\begin{align*}
1 x + 2 y + 3 z &=5 \\
1 x + 3 y + 6 z &=2 \\
2 x + 4 y + 8 z &=10 \\
3 x + 6 y + 12 z &=15.\end{align*}

Notice that equation 3 is just 2 times equation 1 and equation 4 is 3
times equation 1. Therefore, really 3 of the four equations are just
saying that 1\emph{x}+2\emph{y}+3\emph{z}=5. The row reduced matrix
would be

\begin{align*}\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1  &  0  &  0 & 11\\
0  & 1  &  2  &  -3\\
0  &  0  &  0  & 0\\
0  &  0  &  0  &  0
\end{array}\right].\end{align*}

In this example we have a free variable because we only have 2 pivots.
Therefore let \emph{z}=\emph{t}. Then we conclude that

\begin{align*}
x&=11\\
y&=-3-2z=-3-2t\\
z&=t\end{align*}

or

\begin{align*}\begin{bmatrix}
x\\
y\\
z
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
11\\
-3\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+t
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
-2\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.\end{align*}

Here we see that there are actually an \textbf{infinite number of
solutions} depending on the parameter \emph{t}.

Therefore we have constructed examples where we can have \textbf{unique
solutions}, \textbf{no solutions}, or an \textbf{infinite number of
solutions} and thus we see the answer is \textbf{(e)}
hints:
Conditions on one, infinite, or no solutions depend on \textbf{zero}
rows in the matrix, what kind of conditions create those?
